description: Onomatopoeic origin. Compare German klatschen (“to clap, smack, slap”) and Klatsch (“a clapping sound; the din resulting from two or more things colliding”).

entries.meaning: (onomatopoeia) A loud sound, like the crashing together of metal objects.
examples: I heard a clash from the kitchen, and rushed in to find the cat had knocked over some pots and pans.

entries.meaning: (sports) match; a game between two sides.
Opposition; contradiction; such as between differing or contending interests, views, purposes etc.
A combination of garments that do not look good together, especially because of conflicting colours.
examples: She was wearing a horrible clash of red and orange.

entries.meaning: (hurling) An instance of restarting the game after a "dead ball", where it is dropped between two opposing players, who can fight for possession.

verbs.description: clash (third-person singular simple present clashes, present participle clashing, simple past and past participle clashed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to make a clashing sound.

examples: Fans from opposing teams clashed on the streets after the game.
My parents often clashed about minor things, such as the cleaning or shopping rota.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, in games or sports) To face each other in an important game.
(intransitive, of clothes, decor, colours) To fail to look good together; to contrast unattractively; to fail to harmonize.
examples: You can't wear that shirt! It clashes with your trousers.
The hotel room was ugly, and the wallpaper clashed with the carpet.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of events) To coincide, to happen at the same time, thereby rendering it impossible to attend all.
examples: I can't come to your wedding because it clashes with a friend's funeral.
I wanted to take German, but it clashed with art on the timetable.
